title: Synthetic Recap
body:
MILWAUKEE — In a defensive clinic that defied the era’s high-scoring norms, the Indiana Pacers authored a masterpiece of controlled, physical basketball, dismantling the Milwaukee Bucks 109-83 in a 1998 contest that will be remembered for one of the most dominant rebounding performances in NBA history.

The story of the night, and the primary architect of the Bucks' demise, was Pacers center Rik Smits. While his 20 points were efficient, it was his staggering total of 25 rebounds that shattered the spirit of the home team. From the opening tip, Smits was an immovable force in the paint, swallowing every missed shot and extinguishing any chance of a second opportunity for Milwaukee. His work on the glass was not just prolific; it was historic, a testament to sheer will and positioning that left the Bucks frontcourt utterly powerless.

With Smits commanding the interior, the Pacers’ offense operated with ruthless efficiency. Reggie Miller, the team’s fiery leader, paced the scoring with 22 points, picking his spots as the defense collapsed on the dominant Smits. The support was crucial, with Dale Davis adding a double-double of 16 points and 10 boards, forming an impenetrable wall alongside Smits.

For the Bucks, it was a night of profound frustration. Despite a valiant 22-point effort from Glenn Robinson, the team’s offense was suffocated. The inability to secure a rebound—any rebound—with Smits patrolling the lane completely disrupted their rhythm and flow. The final score, a 26-point margin, was a direct reflection of Indiana’s total dominance in the paint, a victory forged on the strength of one man’s unforgettable night on the boards. This was more than a win; it was a declaration of physical supremacy, with Rik Smits as its undisputed king.
